section_title: E Raw Experimental Results for Finding Minimum Dominating Cliques
section_purpose: This section presents raw experimental results for the minimum dominating clique problem, comparing the performance of different GNN-enhanced solvers (using various loss functions) against the original solver on synthetic graph instances.
key_points: Three GNN models were trained for finding minimum dominating cliques, differing in their loss functions (Equation (5) and two variants of Equation (6) with different expected size calculations).
Six GNN-enhanced solvers were created by combining the three models with fast and accurate versions of joint information entropy.
Experiments were run on training, validation, and test data generated from G(n,p) random graphs with edge probability p ∈ (0.4, 0.41) and 50 instances per graph size n.
Results are shown in Tables 5, 6, and 7, comparing the original solver (O) and the GNN-based solvers (labeled (5), (6), and (7) corresponding to their loss functions).

algorithms: GNN models with loss functions from Equations (5) and (6)
Two methods for computing expected set size E(|S|): sum of probabilities and Equation (7)
formulas: Equation (7) for calculating expected set size
datasets: Synthetic graphs generated from G(n,p) with p ∈ (0.4, 0.41), 50 instances per n

dependencies: Understanding of minimum dominating clique problem
reproducibility_notes: GNN architecture details (likely from Appendix A)
Dataset generation parameters: G(n,p) with specific p range and instance count
Details on fast and accurate joint information entropy variants
